channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Macron’s European Political Community Debuts in the Shadow of War
item.description: The French president envisions the European Political Community as a bold way for an independent Europe to flex its muscle. Whether Europe will follow his lead is unclear.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France. One of the president’s obsessions is ensuring that Europe not become a bystander to history, as he puts it.

item.title: Covid Death of Li Wenliang, the Doctor China Tried to Silence
item.description: A New York Times video investigation reveals new details about the death of Dr. Li Wenliang, a national hero who faced censorship after sounding an early alarm on Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Isabelle Qian, Tracy Wen Liu and Chris Buckley

item.title: Some Unlikely Dealers Are Selling Weapons to Ukraine
item.description: New brokers are cashing in as the Biden administration quietly encourages private weapons sales to Ukraine. Oversight is scant in these shadows.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a rocket-propelled grenade launcher outside of Kharkiv in the early days of the war. Ukraine has turned to private arms deals to meet its needs.

item.title: North Korea Launches 2 Ballistic Missiles, Condemning UN Meeting
item.description: They marked the 24th weapons test by the isolated country this year, and came days after Pyongyang fired a missile over Japan for the first time since 2017.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A woman walks by a television airing file footage of a North Korean missile test, at a railway station in Seoul, on Thursday.

item.title: U.N. Agency Renews Plea to Secure Nuclear Plant After Russian Takeover
item.description: Since President Vladimir V. Putin nationalized the Zaporizhzhia facility, its safety has taken on new urgency, the head of the nuclear watchdog said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Internally displaced Ukrainians registering for aid and social services in Dnipro, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Retreat at the Front, Russia Strikes Deep Into Ukraine With Drones
item.description: In an attack in central Ukraine, Russian forces used what Ukrainians said were Iranian-made drones acquired by Moscow as its own arsenal dwindles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Eric Nagourney
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: A local resident sat outside a building destroyed after an airstrike on Bila Tserkva, southwest of Kyiv, on Wednesday.

item.title: Unveiled and Furious: How Iran’s Women-Led Protests Cut to the Heart of National Identity
item.description: The hijabs women are forced to wear have long been a sign of the government’s power. Now, the women-led protests have made them a symbol of a clashing vision of Iran’s future.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran in September, after the death of Mahsa Amini.

item.title: Danish Queen Apologizes After Stripping Royal Titles From 4 Grandchildren
item.description: Prince Joachim, the youngest of Queen Margrethe II’s two sons, has four children who will be affected by the change, which the queen said was “a necessary future-proofing of the monarchy.”
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Agence France-Presse via Ritzau Scanpix
item.media:description: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark in September, as she celebrated the 50th anniversary of her accession to the throne.

item.title: In Israel, a Solemn Yom Kippur Also Creates a Giant Playground
item.description: Yom Kippur, the holiest day in Judaism, brings Israel to a standstill. For the nonobservant, that briefly turns highways into bike trails.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bikers in Tel Aviv on Ayalon Highway, typically one of the busiest roads in the Middle East, during Yom Kippur on Wednesday.

item.title: Baquer Namazi, Held by Iran for 7 Years, Is Released
item.description: The Iranian American is heading to the United Arab Emirates for urgent medical care.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Baquer Namazi in Muscat, Oman, on Wednesday. Mr. Namazi’s family had been pleading for his release for years so he could undergo surgery for arterial blockages.

item.title: Truss Faces Protests During Speech at Her Party’s Conference
item.description: Britain’s beleaguered new prime minister weathered a protest during her set-piece annual speech to deliver an uncompromising message.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss of Britain and her husband, Hugh O’Leary, at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham, England, on Wednesday. Her speech promised “a growing economy and a better future.”

item.title: Australia Aims to Cut Its High Rate of Species Extinctions to Zero
item.description: The country plans to focus on 110 endangered species and 20 habitats, but experts said the initiative was only a start.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rescued koala in South Australia in 2018. Koalas were declared an endangered species earlier this year.

item.title: OPEC Move Shows the Limits of Biden’s Fist-Bump Diplomacy With the Saudis
item.description: OPEC’s decision to curb oil production was a signal that President Biden’s influence over his Gulf allies was far less than he had hoped.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Ben Hubbard
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s decision to support an oil output cut by OPEC and its allies on Wednesday marked another step of distancing from the United States.

item.title: Philippines Lottery Draw Produced 433 Winners. Was It Pure Luck?
item.description: The result of a lotto drawing in the Philippines has set off a national debate about randomness, probability, fraud and human nature.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Richard James Mendoza/NurPhoto via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bettors buying lottery tickets at a mall in Manila in 2018.

item.title: Yascha Mounk on What Democracy Needs to Survive
item.description: The author and educator explains that making diverse democracies work is difficult and offers suggestions on how they can succeed.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen
item.media:description: A marcher at the Canada Day celebrations in July in Ottawa. Yascha Mounk said that Canada was among the countries that had developed a healthy sense of civic and cultural patriotism.

item.title: Scandinavia Offers Hints for Achieving Successful Democracies
item.description: Sweden, Norway, Finland and Denmark consistently rate highly on scales assessing democratic health, but it’s not easy to replicate their systems.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen
item.media:description: Danish voters cast ballots in June on a referendum on whether to overturn Denmark’s opting out of the European Union’s common defense policy after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. The referendum passed.

item.title: Kathmandu Finally Got Tap Water. After a Climate Disaster, It Was Gone.
item.description: A disaster that wiped out a decades-long project to bring pipe-borne water to Nepal’s capital shows the mismatch between slow-moving donor-financed efforts and rapid global warming.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Bhadra Sharma
item.media:credit: Uma Bista for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents south of Kathmandu collecting water at a traditional stone spout, which works only during the rainy season.

item.title: Four Young Leaders Explain Their Roles in the Global Democracy Movement
item.description: Four young leaders explain how they became involved in the global democracy movement and what they have learned so far.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: A Time of Unease and Challenge for Democracy
item.description: With many nations wary of the leadership of the United States, the war in Ukraine poses a test for the West.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, told the Athens Democracy Forum, “I am deeply convinced that democracy will prevail.”

item.title: With Ukraine War, Europe’s Democratic Project Takes on New Urgency
item.description: Panelists at the Athens Democracy Forum said Putin’s invasion has provided a striking example of the importance and power of the democratic idea.
item.dc:creator: Celestine Bohlen
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Given their different histories, Eastern European and Western European nations hold different perspectives on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Democracy Forum panelists said.

item.title: TikTok, Fake News and Obstacles to the Ballot Box
item.description: Last week, experts convened in Athens to discuss disinformation, misinformation and other threats to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri

item.title: In Greece, Democracy and Theater Were Closely Intertwined
item.description: In ancient Greece the great playwrights helped to plant and nurture the seeds of representative government through their characters and plots.
item.dc:creator: David Belcher
item.media:credit: Ken Welsh/Education Images/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The idea of democracy was nurtured in the outdoor amphitheaters that dotted the hillsides throughout the many city-states of ancient Greece.

item.title: In Algeria, Veiled From the World, Past and Future Are Shrouded, Too
item.description: A land of thwarted potential, the country fends off outside influences, political change and some of its own history.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: The Santa Cruz Chapel in Oran, Algeria, last month. For the ossified politico-military establishment that runs the country, tourism and foreign investment are suspect, as are theaters, cinemas or book stores.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: OPEC’s decision to curb oil production.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s Minister of Energy Abdulaziz bin Salman, center, and other OPEC Plus representatives in Vienna on Wednesday.

item.title: 视觉调查：李文亮医生的最后时刻
item.description: 时报的视觉调查团队审阅了李文亮的医疗记录，独家采访了一位目击了抢救过程的医生，揭示了关于李文亮病情和死亡的重要新细节。
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Isabelle Qian, Tracy Wen Liu, Drew Jordan and Jeff Bernier

item.title: Inside the Final Days of the Doctor China Tried to Silence
item.description: A New York Times video investigation reveals new details about Dr. Li Wenliang’s illness and death from Covid-19 based on medical records and an exclusive interview with a key witness.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Isabelle Qian, Tracy Wen Liu, Drew Jordan and Jeff Bernier

item.title: Patricia Cloherty, Trailblazing Venture Capitalist, Dies at 80
item.description: A logger’s daughter, she was among the first women to thrive in the high-risk, high-reward field and a key backer of fledgling Russian companies in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan
item.media:description: Patricia Cloherty was a rare woman in the field of venture capital who became a leader in financing Russian companies after the collapse of the Soviet Union.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.S. Believes Ukrainians Were Behind a Killing in Russia
item.description: Plus arming Taiwan to deter China and OPEC cuts oil production.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Daria Dugina’s memorial service in Moscow in August. U.S. intelligence agencies believe that parts of the Ukrainian government authorized the attack that killed her.

item.title: Climate Change Made Summer Hotter and Drier Worldwide, Study Finds
item.description: Europe, China and North America were parched by extreme heat that would have been ‘virtually impossible’ without the effects of global warming, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: A field destroyed by a brush fire in the drought-ravaged village of Xinyao in Jiangxi Province, China, in August.

item.title: Jerzy Urban, Acerbic Communist Turned Free-Speech Hero, Dies at 89
item.description: He spent the 1980s as the Polish regime’s sarcastic spokesman, then transformed himself into a controversial media entrepreneur in the ’90s.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: U.S. Believes Ukrainians Were Behind an Assassination in Russia
item.description: American officials said they were not aware of the plan ahead of time for the attack that killed Daria Dugina and that they had admonished Ukraine over it.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Adam Goldman, Adam Entous and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Daria Dugina’s memorial service in Moscow in August. U.S. intelligence agencies believe that parts of the Ukrainian government authorized the attack that killed her.

item.title: Biden Releases More Reserve Oil and Pushes Companies to Keep Up Production
item.description: U.S. officials have been in talks with oil-producing countries in an effort to prevent global oil prices from rising sharply.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: OPEC members led by Saudi Arabia and its 10 allied members headed by Russia will meet in Vienna for the first time since spring 2020.

item.title: Russian Journalist Who Protested War Escapes House Arrest
item.description: Marina Ovsyannikova said in a Telegram post that she considered herself innocent of the two-month sentence imposed by a Moscow court.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Marina Ovsyannikova, a former state television employee who gained fame after protesting on air, during a court hearing in Moscow in July.

item.title: Putin Signs Annexation Laws as Russia Loses Ground in Ukraine
item.description: Russian state television trumpeted the news, while playing down or ignoring the fact that Moscow’s forces are in retreat in multiple parts of the front line.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed a rally and concert in Red Square last week celebrating Russia’s illegal annexation of four Ukrainian provinces.

item.title: Balancing Extremes
item.description: The Federal Reserve is trying to tame inflation without wrecking the economy.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Julia Nikhinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, warned that increasing interest rates would be painful for the U.S. economy — but said curbing growth to contain price increases was essential.

item.title: U.S. Aims to Turn Taiwan Into Giant Weapons Depot
item.description: Officials say Taiwan needs to become a “porcupine” with enough weapons to hold out if the Chinese military blockades and invades it, even if Washington decides to send troops.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese military exercises in July. The United States has approved several weapons packages for the island.

item.title: Whatever Happened to Those Self-Service Passport Kiosks at Airports?
item.description: More than 80 percent of all travelers entering the U.S. are now verified by facial recognition. The loss of older, seemingly more convenient methods has many perplexed. And then there are the privacy issues.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy

item.title: What Does Sustainable Living Look Like? Maybe Like Uruguay
item.description: No greater challenge faces humanity than reducing emissions without backsliding into preindustrial poverty. One tiny country is leading the way.
item.dc:creator: Noah Gallagher Shannon
item.media:credit: Alessandro Cinque for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gauchos at the Pintado wind farm in Corral de Piedra, Uruguay.

item.title: Nobel Prize in Chemistry Is Awarded to 3 Scientists for Work ‘Snapping Molecules Together’
item.description: Carolyn R. Bertozzi, Morten Meldal and K. Barry Sharpless were honored for their advances in “click chemistry,” which has played a role in treating and diagnosing illnesses.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht, Euan Ward and Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Christine Olsson/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Nobel committee said that findings by the three scientists had “taken chemistry into the era of functionalism” and were “bringing the greatest benefit to humankind.”

item.title: Japan expels a Russian diplomat, a retaliatory move as relations deteriorate.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Tokyo. Relations between Japan and Russia have been deteriorating.

item.title: Russians Fleeing the Draft Find an Unlikely Haven in Kyrgyzstan
item.description: Tens of thousands of men have ended up in places like Kyrgyzstan, a former Soviet territory, that normally see few refugees but are willing to take them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri, a 36-year-old artist from Siberia, took three days to get by bus and train to Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, where he now lives in a 20-bed hostel room.

item.title: Ukraine Expels Some Russian Troops in South
item.description: Moscow’s retreat has pulled back the curtain on a panorama of ruined towns and empty villages left in its wake.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops moving through the recently recaptured village of Yatskivka on Tuesday. Ukraine has recaptured cities in the northeast, the east and now the south.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine gains ground in south
item.description: Plus Elon Musk suggests buying Twitter at his original price and North Korea fires a missile over Japan
item.dc:creator: Jessica Cheung and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken during the government-arranged tour for journalists showing a destroyed bridge in Sviatohirsk on Monday.

item.title: After the Storm, the Mold: Warming Is Worsening Another Costly Disaster
item.description: Mold in homes is a costly crisis that often accompanies hurricanes and flooding, and climate change is amplifying the rain that feeds outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin and Emily Kask
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times

item.title: A U.N. investigation finds that Russian forces are torturing civilian and military prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: An apartment building was heavily damaged by Russian bombs in Bakhmut in September. Local residents said that at least two Ukrainian civilians, a mother and son, were killed.

item.title: 4 Women Will Staff U.K. Base in Antarctica
item.description: They emerged from an applicant pool of thousands to run the world’s most southerly post office, monitor penguins and manage the wild landscape on Goudier Island.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.media:description: Port Lockroy base on Goudier Island is managed by the U.K. Antarctic Heritage Trust. Assignment there is not for the faint hearted.

item.title: A new package of U.S. military aid will speed more mobile rocket launchers to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The M142 HIMARS, or High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, has been a key part of the U.S.’s military support for Ukraine. This is one such unit, deployed during military exercises in Latvia last month.

item.title: Ukraine’s Top Diplomat Tries to Counter Russia’s Narrative on Africa Tour
item.description: “I arrived here and I hear, ‘Russia and Ukraine are one people,’” Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, said in Senegal on the first stop of his 10-day trip across Africa.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Mady Camara
item.media:description: Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, speaking at the United Nations Security Council in September.

item.title: Hidden in 54 Corpses, a Revelation About Ancient Greece
item.description: DNA from a 2,500-year-old battlefield in Sicily reveals that mercenary soldiers were common, if not the Homeric ideal.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:description: A mass grave of troops from the second Battle of Himera in Sicily in 409 B.C. One-fourth of the combatants are thought to have been mercenaries, compared to two-thirds in the first Battle of Himera seven decades earlier.

item.title: Iran Attacks Kurdish Positions Across the Border in Iraq
item.description: Tehran has blamed Kurdish groups for fomenting some of the protests that have convulsed Iran for almost three weeks.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Damage from an Iranian attack near the city of Suleimaniyah, Iraq, last week.

item.title: Florida’s GOP Leaders Opposed Climate Aid. Now They’re Depending on It.
item.description: Senior Republican politicians in the state have opposed federal action against global warming, which is making storms like Hurricane Ian more destructive.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: Damage to the Sanibel Causeway, the only road in or out of Sanibel Island, in southwest Florida on Sept. 29.

item.title: Rebekah Vardy Ordered to Pay Legal Fees in ‘Wagatha Christie’ Case
item.description: Ms. Vardy will pay 90 percent of Coleen Rooney’s legal costs, an estimated $1.7 million, after losing a libel case that proved irresistible to the British press.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Rebekah Vardy in London in May, arriving for a hearing in the so-called Wagatha Christie libel case.

item.title: Protecting the Peatlands of Ireland as Fuel Costs Skyrocket
item.description: One in seven Irish households still burn peat for heat. New rules are aimed at discouraging a practice that many consider part of the culture.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seamus Caulfield, a retired archaeology professor, cutting peat using a traditional angled spade called a sleán, on his family’s land in Belderrig, Ireland.

item.title: Tear Gas, a Stampede, and an Indonesian Family Shattered
item.description: Muhammad Yulianto and Devi Ratna Sari took their young son to his first soccer match. The young couple were among the 125 who died in the tragedy at the Indonesian stadium.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Muhammad Alfiansyah, 11, with photographs of his parents, in Malang on Tuesday.

item.title: A Public Health Success Story
item.description: We revisit the subject of Covid and racial inequities.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A health care worker from Alabama Regional Medical Services administering a Covid vaccine in Birmingham, Ala., in 2021.

item.title: Trial Opens for Bruce Lehrmann, Man Accused of Rape in Australia’s Parliament House
item.description: The trial of the Australian man accused of sexually assaulting Brittany Higgins will be viewed against the backdrop of the global #MeToo movement.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins arriving at Supreme Court in Canberra, Australia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia’s War in Ukraine Sends Swedish Marines Into the Arms of NATO
item.description: Russia’s war in Ukraine has sent marines from famously neutral Sweden into the arms of NATO, where they have been working with American forces.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Kenny Holston
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American and Swedish marines participating in a military exercise near Berga Naval Base in Sweden.

item.title: What Video Footage Reveals About the Protests in Iran
item.description: The New York Times analyzed dozens of videos circulating online for insights about what is propelling the demonstrations, and how women are leading the movement.
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Haley Willis

item.title: Climate Change for Preschoolers: ‘Octonauts’ Explores Unmapped Ground
item.description: There are few books, shows or other tools to help parents and teachers talk to preschoolers about global warming. “Octonauts: Above and Beyond” is one of the first to try.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
